jsx.core
Class RegExpLikes

java.lang.Object
  js.Disposable
      jsx.core.RegExpLikes

public final class RegExpLikes
extends Disposable

A utility class providing the static methods operating on regular expressions.

Users are encouraged to use the utilities provided by this class instead of the opaque methods of RegExpLike or JsRegExp in consideration of the reuse benefit for re-compilation results.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org

Method Detail

global

public static final boolean global(RegExpLike r)

Gets the global field of the current regular expression instance.

The global field is a read-only boolean property of regular expression instances. It specifies whether a particular regular expression performs global matching, that is, whether it was created with the "g" attribute.

Parameters:
r - The current regular expression.
Returns:
The value of the global field of the regular expression.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
Js.re(String, String)

ignoreCase

public static final boolean ignoreCase(RegExpLike r)

Gets the ignoreCase field of the current regular expression instance.

The ignoreCase field is a read-only boolean property of regular expression instances. It specifies whether a particular regular expression performs case-insensitive matching, that is, whether it was created with the "i" attribute.

Parameters:
r - The current regular expression.
Returns:
The value of the ignoreCase field of the regular expression.
Since:
1.0

lastIndex

public static final java.lang.Integer lastIndex(RegExpLike r)

Gets the lastIndex field of the current regular expression instance.

The lastIndex field is a read/write property of regular expression instances. For regular expressions with the "g" attribute set, it contains an integer that specifies the character position immediately following the last match found by the exec(js.RegExpLike, Object) and test(js.RegExpLike, Object) methods. These methods use this property as the starting point for the next search they conduct. This allows you to call those methods repeatedly, to loop through all matches in a string. Note that lastIndex is not used by regular expressions that do not have the "g" attribute set and do not represent global patterns.

This property is read/write, so you can set it at any time to specify where in the target string the next search should begin. exec(js.RegExpLike, Object) and test(js.RegExpLike, Object) automatically reset lastIndex to 0 when they fail to find a match (or another match). If you begin to search a new string after a successful match of some other string, you have to explicitly set this property to 0.

Parameters:
r - The current regular expression.
Returns:
The value of the lastIndex field of the regular expression.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
lastIndex(js.RegExpLike, Integer), exec(js.RegExpLike, Object), test(js.RegExpLike, Object)

lastIndex

public static final java.lang.Integer lastIndex(RegExpLike r,
                                                java.lang.Integer lastIndex)

Sets the lastIndex field of the current regular expression instance.

The lastIndex field is a read/write property of regular expression instances. For regular expressions with the "g" attribute set, it contains an integer that specifies the character position immediately following the last match found by the exec(js.RegExpLike, Object) and test(js.RegExpLike, Object) methods. These methods use this property as the starting point for the next search they conduct. This allows you to call those methods repeatedly, to loop through all matches in a string. Note that lastIndex is not used by regular expressions that do not have the "g" attribute set and do not represent global patterns.

This property is read/write, so you can set it at any time to specify where in the target string the next search should begin. exec(js.RegExpLike, Object) and test(js.RegExpLike, Object) automatically reset lastIndex to 0 when they fail to find a match (or another match). If you begin to search a new string after a successful match of some other string, you have to explicitly set this property to 0.

Parameters:
r - The current regular expression.
lastIndex - The new lastIndex to set.
Returns:
The new value of the lastIndex.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
lastIndex(js.RegExpLike), exec(js.RegExpLike, Object), test(js.RegExpLike, Object)

source

public static final java.lang.String source(RegExpLike r)

Gets the source field of the current regular expression instance.

The source field is a read-only string property of regular expression instances. It contains the text of the regular expression. This text does not include the delimiting slashes used in regular-expression literals, and it does not include the "g", "i", and "m" attributes.

Parameters:
r - The current regular expression.
Returns:
The source text of the regular expression.
Since:
1.0

exec

public static final ArrayLike<?> exec(RegExpLike r,
                                      java.lang.Object s)

Performs powerful, general-purpose pattern matching with the current regular expression instance.

This method is the most powerful of all the regular expression and string pattern-matching methods. It is a general-purpose method that is somewhat more complex to use than test(js.RegExpLike, Object), StringLikes.search(js.StringLike, RegExpLike), StringLikes.replace(js.StringLike, RegExpLike, String), and StringLikes.match(js.StringLike, RegExpLike).

This invocation searches string for text that matches the current regular expression. If it finds a match, it returns an array of results; otherwise, it returns null. Element 0 of the returned array is the matched text. Element 1 is the text that matched the first parenthesized subexpression, if any, within the current regular expression. Element 2 contains the text that matched the second subexpression, and so on. The array length property specifies the number of elements in the array, as usual. In addition to the array elements and the length property, the value returned by the invocation also has two other properties. The index property (see ArrayLikes.index(js.ArrayLike)) specifies the character position of the first character of the matched text. The input property (see ArrayLikes.input(js.ArrayLike)) refers to s. This returned array is the same as the array that is returned by the StringLikes.match(js.StringLike, RegExpLike) method, when invoked on a non-global regular expression instance.

When this method is invoked on a non-global pattern, it performs the search and returns the result described earlier. When the current instance is a global regular expression, however, the invocation behaves in a slightly more complex way. It begins searching string at the character position specified by the lastIndex property (see lastIndex(js.RegExpLike) and lastIndex(js.RegExpLike, Integer)) of the current regular expression. When it finds a match, it sets lastIndex to the position of the first character after the match. This means that you can invoke this method repeatedly in order to loop through all matches in a string. When the invocation cannot find any more matches, it returns null and resets lastIndex to zero. If you begin searching a new string immediately after successfully finding a match in another string, you must be careful to manually reset lastIndex to zero.

Note that this invocation always includes full details of every match in the array it returns, whether or not the current regular expression is a global pattern. This is where this method differs from StringLikes.match(js.StringLike, RegExpLike), which returns much less information when used with global patterns. Calling this method repeatedly in a loop is the only way to obtain complete pattern-matching information for a global pattern.

Parameters:
r - The current regular expression.
s - The string to be tested.
Returns:
An array containing the results of the match or undefined null if no match was found.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a TypeError if this method is invoked with an instance that is not a regular expression. See Js.err(Object) and JsTypeError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
See Also:
lastIndex(js.RegExpLike), lastIndex(js.RegExpLike, Integer), test(js.RegExpLike, Object), StringLikes.match(js.StringLike, RegExpLike), StringLikes.replace(js.StringLike, RegExpLike, String), StringLikes.replace(js.StringLike, RegExpLike, StringLike), StringLikes.replace(js.StringLike, RegExpLike, js.core.JsFunction), StringLikes.search(js.StringLike, RegExpLike)

test

public static final boolean test(RegExpLike r,
                                 java.lang.Object s)

Tests whether a string contains the pattern represented by the current regular expression.

Parameters:
r - The current regular expression.
s - The string to be tested.
Returns:
true if s contains text that matches the current regular expression; false otherwise.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - JavaScript throws a TypeError if this method is invoked with an instance that is not a regular expression. See Js.err(Object) and JsTypeError for JS Simulation.
Since:
1.0
